Aeclanum(also spelledAeculanum,lang-itEclano,lang-grΑικούλανον)it iconAeclanunon theTreccaniItalian Encyclopedia Treccaniwas an ancient town ofSamnium, southernItaly, c. 25 km east-southeast ofBeneventum, on theVia Appia. It lies inPasso di Mirabella, near the modernMirabella Eclano.
article.heading: Location
article.paragraph: File:Aeclanum (Ruins-03).jpgthumbleft200pxView of the townAeclanum was on a promontory naturally defended, to some extent, by a steep slope on the south side down to the river Calore, while the north side lay open towards the crest of the ridge that carried what under theRoman Empirebecame theVia Appia. This led throughAmpsanctusLacus AmpsanctustoAquilonia, ItalyAquiloniaandVenusia. Another route toApulia, the Via Aurelia Aeclanensis diverged here, leading through modernArianotoHerdoniae. The road from Aeclanum toAbellinum(mod.Avellino) may also follow an ancient line. Today there are ruins of the city walls, of anaqueduct (Roman)aqueduct, baths and anamphitheatre; nearly 400 inscriptions have also been discovered. Excavation has revealed a long history of pre-Roman settlement."AECLANUM (Eclano) Italy" in ''The Princeton Encyclopedia of Classical Sites''EB19111Aeclanum1Aeclanum
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: Aeclanum became the chief town of theHirpini, afterBeneventoBeneventumhad become aRomeRomancolony.Lucius Cornelius SullaSullacaptured it in 89 BC by setting on fire the wooden breastwork by which it was defended, and sacked it. It quickly recovered, new fortifications were erected, and it became amunicipium.Hadrian, who repaired the Via Appia from Beneventum to this point, made it acolonia (Roman)colonia. With theLombardsLombardinvasion of Italy it was annexed to theDuchy of Benevento, but was captured and destroyed byByzantine EmpireunderConstans IIin 663 and never recovered, being reduced to a small hamlet known as Quintodecimo, a name that referred to its distance of 15 miles from Benevento.
article.heading: Bishopric
article.paragraph: Aeclanum became aChristianityChristianepiscopal see, whose best knownbishopwasJulian of Eclanum, who was consecrated byPope Innocent Iin about 417. He refused to sign the condemnation ofPelagianismissued by Pope Innocent's successor,Pope Zosimus, and carried on a war of writings againstAugustine of Hippo. It has been thought that the diocese was united to that ofFrigentoFrequentiumas early as the 5th century, but there is mention of Quintodecimo as asuffragansee of Benevento in 969 and 1058. From 1059 it was definitively united with Frequentium.Giuseppe Cappelletti,''Le Chiese d'Italia dalla loro origine sino ai nostri giorni'', Venezia 1864, vol.
